meeting_annotations.speaker: Burcu Gurkan
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay so we're going to start with the first question. What is the most important scientific question in your field?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think for me it's how do we make materials that can selectively take CO2 out of the air.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Pratik Dholabhai
meeting_annotations.transcript: I would say for me it's how do we make materials that can take CO2 out of the ocean.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker is in an office with a large whiteboard covered in chemical equations and diagrams.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's interesting. I mean the concentration is so much higher in flue gas. Why not just go after that? I mean the advantage of the air of course is you can do it anywhere you don't have to be at a point source. But the ocean you have to be at the ocean. So why the ocean versus flue gas? I mean the ocean is a huge carbon sink so it's important to get it out of the ocean but it's still a pretty low concentration compared to a point source. And so you know the thermodynamics are just going to kill you I think in terms of the energy cost of getting it out. I mean it's already bad enough from air. From the ocean it's even more dilute. So I don't know. I mean maybe there's some trick with the pH of the ocean or something you can do but I'm not sure I see the advantage there. I mean it's a big problem but I don't see the advantage of going after the ocean. Maybe you can enlighten me.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker constructively challenges the previous idea by outlining thermodynamic and logistical hurdles.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Leo Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I think that's a great point. I think the advantage of the ocean is that it's a huge reservoir and so if you can get it out of the ocean you can make a big dent in the problem. And I think there are some tricks you can play with the pH. There's a recent paper in Nature that showed that you can use a bipolar membrane to split water and then use the protons to acidify the ocean and drive off the CO2. And then you can use the hydroxide to raise the pH back up and you can do this in a closed loop. So I think there are some clever things you can do. I'll put the article in the chat.
meeting_annotations.other: At 01:54, a chat message from Jenny Yang appears, providing a link to the article just mentioned by the speaker.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Green
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I saw that paper it's pretty cool. I think the challenge there is the cost of the bipolar membrane. They're not cheap and you have to have a lot of them to make a difference. And then you have to worry about fouling and all that stuff. So I think it's a cool idea but I'm not sure it's practical. I think a better way to go is to use a liquid sorbent. You can use an amine or something like that and you can just bubble the air through it and then you can heat it up to release the CO2 and you can do that in a closed loop. And I think that's a more practical way to go. I think the challenge there is the energy cost of heating it up but I think there are ways to get around that. You can use waste heat from a power plant or something like that. So I think that's a more practical way to go.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker acknowledges the previous idea before pivoting to a counter-proposal, comparing the practical challenges of both.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Leo Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah that's a good point. I think the challenge with the liquid sorbents is that they're corrosive.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Green
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah that's true but I think there are ways to get around that. You can use a different kind of amine or you can use a different kind of solvent. So I think there are ways to get around that. I think the other thing is that you can use a solid sorbent. You can use a metal organic framework or something like that and you can just pack it in a column and then you can just flow the air through it and then you can just heat it up to release the CO2 and you can do that in a closed loop and I think that's a more practical way to go.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Leo Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I think that's a good point. I think the challenge with the solid sorbents is that they're not very stable. They tend to degrade over time.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Green
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah that's true but I think there are ways to get around that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: So Matt you mentioned metal organic frameworks. I think that's a really interesting area. We've been working on that for a while and I think there's a lot of potential there. I think the challenge is to find a material that's stable enough and that has a high enough capacity. But I think we're getting there. We have a new material that we're really excited about. It's a cobalt-based material and it has a really high capacity for CO2 and it's also very stable. So we're pretty excited about that.
meeting_annotations.other: At 05:00, a chat message from Matt Green appears with a DOI link, likely related to the material being discussed.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Leo Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's really cool. I'd love to hear more about that. I think the other thing that's interesting is to use electrochemistry to do the separation. You can use an electrochemical cell to split water and then use the protons to acidify the ocean and drive off the CO2 and then you can use the hydroxide to raise the pH back up and you can do this in a closed loop.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker circles back to his earlier idea about ocean-based capture, re-framing it around electrochemistry.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah that's interesting. I mean the electrochemistry is a really hot area right now and I think there's a lot of potential there. But I think the challenge is the energy cost. I mean you're talking about a lot of electricity and so you have to have a renewable source of electricity and then you have to have a very efficient process. And I think that's the challenge. I mean we've been working on that as well. We have a new process that we're really excited about. It's a flow battery process and we think we can get the energy cost down to a reasonable level. So we're pretty excited about that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Schell
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's really cool. I'd love to hear more about that. I think the other thing that's interesting is to use biology to do the separation. You can use algae or something like that and you can just grow it in a pond and then you can just harvest it and then you can just burn it. And you can do that in a closed loop and I think that's a more practical way to go.
meeting_annotations.other: At 06:42, a chat message from Leo Liu appears saying 'Thanks!'.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Green
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I think that's a really interesting idea. I think the challenge there is the land use. You have to have a lot of land to do that. And if you're using land that could be used for growing food then you're not really solving the problem. You're just moving it around. So I think you have to have a source of non-arable land to do that. And then you have to worry about the cost of harvesting and processing the algae. They're not cheap and you have to have a lot of them to make a difference. And then you have to worry about fouling and all that stuff. So I think it's a cool idea but I'm not sure it's practical.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I think that's a really good point. I mean the land use is a huge issue and I think that's one of the reasons why people are looking at the ocean because there's a lot of ocean. But I think the other thing is that you can use a different kind of biology. You can use a microbe or something like that and you can just grow it in a bioreactor and then you can just harvest it and then you can just burn it and you can do that in a closed loop and I think that's a more practical way to go.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Burcu Gurkan
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay so we've heard a lot of great ideas. We've heard about the ocean we've heard about liquid sorbents we've heard about solid sorbents we've heard about electrochemistry and we've heard about biology. So I think we have a lot of good ideas to work with. So I think the next step is to try to figure out which of these ideas is the most promising and I think the way to do that is to do a techno-economic analysis.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker acts as a facilitator, summarizing the discussion and proposing a next step.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I think that's a great idea. I think we should do a techno-economic analysis of all of these ideas and I think we should also do a life cycle analysis to make sure that we're not just moving the problem around.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Burcu Gurkan
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay so I think that's a great plan. meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
